G.L. c. 208 \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208 § 28, a custody order “may be modified if the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

G.L. c. 209C \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208 § 28, G.L. c. 209C § 20, and G.L. c. 215 § 6, as the original custody order was issued by the Norfolk Probate and Family Court and both parties continue to reside in Massachusetts.

Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Rachel Thompson, and respectfully submits this Complaint for Modification of Custody Order pursuant to G.L. c. 208 § 28, G.L. c. 209C § 20, and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7, seeking an adjustment of the existing custody order entered by this Honorable Court on May 15, 2018, due to a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the minor child, Emily Thompson (age 12).

G.L. c. 215 \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208 § 28, G.L. c. 209C § 20, and G.L. c. 215 § 6, as the original custody order was issued by the Norfolk Probate and Family Court and both parties continue to reside in Massachusetts.

Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 82.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 82.

Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 4.proposition: I certify that on this date, I have served a true and correct copy of this Complaint for Modification upon Daniel Thompson, Defendant, by [certified mail / hand delivery / in accordance with Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 4].

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 custody order, a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred affecting the welfare of the child, as defined in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) and Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts and articulates the ‘real advantage’ standard and best-interests analysis for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30. It does not address modification of an existing custody order based on a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances,’ nor does it define that phrase or set out a standard for when post-judgment changes justify modifying custody. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition about a material and substantial change since a 2018 custody order.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 custody order, a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred affecting the welfare of the child, as defined in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) and Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: Rosenthal does discuss the statutory and common-law standard that a modification of custody requires a post-judgment "material and substantial change in circumstances" affecting the child’s welfare, citing G.L. c. 208, § 28 and cases like Fuller v. Fuller. But the court holds that, on the facts before it, no such material and substantial change had occurred; relocation and a court-imposed temporary custody shift were explicitly found insufficient. Thus, Rosenthal is authority for the standard, not for the proposition that such a change has occurred in a later (2018–present) case.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: These circumstances constitute a material change justifying modification under Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition refers to “these circumstances” constituting a material change justifying modification. Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case that assumes a modification complaint is properly before the court and then articulates the best‑interests standard for removal when parents share joint physical custody. The opinion does not discuss or decide what circumstances amount to a “material change” warranting modification; instead, it focuses on how to evaluate the child’s best interests once the modification/removal issue is already joined. Thus it does not support the specific proposition about what constitutes a material change.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances ... only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]….’”

(The SJC cites this ALI standard descriptively but does not adopt or apply it as the governing rule for material change.)

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: These circumstances constitute a material change justifying modification under Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: This Murray decision involves removal and child support modification; it does not analyze whether the circumstances at issue constitute a “material change” justifying modification under Mason v. Coleman or Custody of Vaughn. The court applies the Yannas ‘real advantage/best interests’ framework to a removal request and then addresses child support using the Child Support Guidelines and G.L. c. 208, § 28, but does not articulate any general rule that particular circumstances amount to a material change. Citing Murray for the general proposition that certain circumstances are a material change is therefore inaccurate or at least unsupported by this opinion’s reasoning.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “On July 10, 2012, the mother filed a complaint for modification alleging, as a change in circumstances, that she was to be married on August 3, 2012, to a resident of Danville, California. For this reason, the complaint sought removal of the minor children to California… The father filed his own complaint for modification, wherein he sought to (1) reduce his child support obligation… In support of his complaint for modification, the father alleged as a material and substantial change of circumstances the mother’s remarriage… Although the father alleged that there had been a material change of circumstances, the judge here was correct to apply those guidelines to the parties’ updated financial circumstances.”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: These circumstances constitute a material change justifying modification under Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn is an initial custody determination and an appellate remand for further findings on the impact of domestic violence; it does not analyze or apply the standard for modification based on a material change in circumstances. The opinion nowhere discusses Mason v. Coleman–type or Murray v. Super–type ‘material change’ doctrine or any analogous modification framework. Citing Vaughn for the proposition that particular post‑judgment circumstances constitute a material change justifying modification misuses the case’s holding and context.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary…”

Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the best interests of the child are paramount in all custody determinations.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that, in removal cases under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the controlling standard is the best interests of the child and that this standard cannot be contracted away in a separation agreement. The court emphasizes that the Probate Court’s jurisdiction and the child’s welfare/best interests are paramount over the parties’ agreement, which aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts treat the child’s best interests as paramount in custody-related determinations. Although focused on removal, it clearly grounds the decision in the best-interests standard.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, and the standard of proof which it requires cannot be written off by the parties. The best interests of the child will control where there is a question as to whether the child will be removed from the Commonwealth. The jurisdiction of the Probate Court over the minor children of divorced parties may not be ousted by the terms of a separation agreement, and the court may, where the best interests of the child dictate, disregard the agreement.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the best interests of the child are paramount in all custody determinations.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely frames the governing principle in custody matters as the welfare of the child and cites earlier Massachusetts cases for that rule. By quoting and reaffirming that “the welfare of the child” is the “dominating rule” and “controlling consideration” in custody determinations, the court confirms that the child’s best interests are paramount. This aligns with the claimed proposition about Massachusetts courts’ consistent approach to custody determinations.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987).raw_text: Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987)
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the best interests of the child are paramount in all custody determinations.
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that a Probate Court judge must determine custody based on the best interests of the children and cites earlier Massachusetts authority for that rule. While this single case cannot by itself prove a long historical pattern of ‘consistent’ holdings, it clearly applies and reaffirms the best-interests standard as the governing, paramount consideration in custody determinations under Massachusetts law.
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987).relevant_excerpt: "Finally, Anthony maintains that the grant of custody of Rosemary and Tony to Sonja was wrong. A Probate Court judge must settle custody in a manner that advances the best interests of the children. Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402 (1981), and cases cited. The decision of which parent will promote a child’s best interests ‘is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.’"

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.proposition: A parent’s change in health or ability to provide physical care is a recognized basis for modification.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns child support arrearages, equitable credits, and modification/termination dates based on which parent the children reside with and who is actually supporting them. It does not discuss any change in a parent’s health or physical ability to care for a child as a basis for modification. The modification in Rosen is grounded in changes in the children’s residence and financial support arrangements, not parental health or caregiving capacity.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Applying the principles we have just set out to the facts of this case, we conclude that the judge was warranted in allowing an equitable credit of $500 per month for the father’s direct support of Elliot from January 1, 2007, to August 11, 2011. It is undisputed that Elliot moved into the father’s home no later than January 1, 2007… It is also undisputed that Elliot received adequate support from the father while living in the father’s home, and that the mother was relieved of supporting Elliot during that period.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A parent’s change in health or ability to provide physical care is a recognized basis for modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the standard for awarding custody—namely, the welfare and best interests of the child and the need to consider all relevant factors and parental environments. It does not discuss modification standards based on a change in a parent’s health or physical caregiving ability, nor does it recognize such a change as a specific basis for modification. Therefore, it does not support the claimed proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment and under the primary care of her father at his home and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.raw_text: Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984)
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: The Court’s duty to protect a child’s safety and emotional wellbeing requires modification when an existing custodial arrangement places the child at risk.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on determining parental unfitness and then requiring a more detailed dispositional order that considers the children’s best interests, particularly sibling relationships and kinship placement. It does not state or clearly imply a general duty of the court to modify an existing custodial arrangement when that arrangement places a child at risk; instead, it critiques the lack of findings guiding the Department’s future placement decisions. The language is about adequacy of findings and best‑interests analysis, not about a continuing judicial duty to modify custody due to risk under an existing arrangement.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests and issued more than a broad dispositional order committing them to the permanent custody of the department… Although a simple commitment order is all that is required by G. L. c. 119, § 26, … in this case, the judge should have given the department some guidance regarding the ultimate placement of the children and visitation by family members.”

Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. 117 (2001.proposition: The Court’s duty to protect a child’s safety and emotional wellbeing requires modification when an existing custodial arrangement places the child at risk.
Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. 117 (2001.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on whether the ADA applies as a defense in termination-of-parental-rights proceedings and on findings of parental unfitness, not on modifying an existing custodial arrangement to protect a child. The court discusses the best interests of the child in the context of termination and adoption, but it does not articulate any rule about a court’s duty to modify existing custody when a current arrangement places the child at risk. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. 117 (2001.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that proceedings to terminate parental rights do not constitute ‘services, programs, or activities’ for the purposes of 42 U.S.C. § 12132, and therefore, the ADA is not a defense to such proceedings. In our view, the parents’ rights are secondary to the child’s best interests and thus, the proper focus of termination proceedings is the welfare of the child. G. L. c. 210, § 3.”

Mayo v. Mayo, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 1123 (20.raw_text: Mayo v. Mayo, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 1123 (2011) (Rule 1:28 decision)
Mayo v. Mayo, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 1123 (20.proposition: The Court may fashion an order that both reflects the child’s best interests and affords the non‑custodial parent reasonable parenting time consistent with their abilities.

Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).proposition: The Court may fashion an order that both reflects the child’s best interests and affords the non‑custodial parent reasonable parenting time consistent with their abilities.
Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on restricting a non‑custodial parent’s religious speech and conduct with the children when it causes substantial emotional harm, not on crafting an order that ensures "reasonable parenting time consistent with their abilities." While the court does speak broadly about balancing parental liberties with the children’s best interests and preserving contact with both parents, it does not set out or discuss a standard for defining or guaranteeing reasonable parenting time for the non‑custodial parent. Thus, it does not directly support the specific proposition stated.
Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).relevant_excerpt: "Whether the harm found to exist amounts to the ‘substantial harm’ required to justify interference with the defendant’s liberty interest is a close question, especially because there is considerable value in ‘frequent and continuing contact’ between the child and both parents, and ‘contact with the parents’ separate religious preferences.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 234. ... In balancing these conflicting interests, fully aware of the complexities and nuances involved, we conclude that the judge’s findings support her order in paragraph 5 of the judgment."
